PGA.description: The design map adjusted maximum expected ground acceleration at the site due to earthquake shaking, reflecting short-period seismic demand that strongly affects stiff structures and foundations.

sentences: Bridges experiencing low seismic demand with PGA values up to 0.2 are generally subject to minimal earthquake-induced forces, requiring standard design considerations for seismic resilience.
Bridges under moderate seismic demand with PGA values between 0.2 and 0.4 need enhanced design features to ensure structural integrity during moderate earthquake events.
High seismic demand bridges with PGA values between 0.4 and 0.6 must incorporate advanced engineering techniques to withstand significant seismic forces and prevent structural damage.
Bridges facing very high seismic demand with PGA values between 0.6 and 0.8 require rigorous seismic design and retrofitting strategies to maintain safety and functionality during strong earthquakes.

Extreme seismic demand bridges with PGA values exceeding 0.8 are exposed to severe earthquake forces, necessitating specialized engineering solutions and continuous monitoring to ensure structural safety and performance.

PGA.title: Design Peak Ground Acceleration

SS.description: The mapped short-period spectral acceleration at the site before site soil effects are applied, representing seismic demand on short-period structural components.

sentences: Bridges experiencing low seismic demand with SS values up to 0.5 are generally subject to minimal seismic forces, allowing for standard design considerations without significant seismic enhancements.

Bridges with moderate seismic demand, having SS values between 0.5 and 1.0, require careful design to ensure structural resilience against moderate seismic activity, often incorporating basic seismic detailing.

High seismic demand on bridges, indicated by SS values between 1.0 and 1.5, necessitates advanced seismic design strategies, including the use of ductile materials and energy dissipation systems to maintain structural integrity.

Bridges facing very high seismic demand with SS values between 1.5 and 2.0 must be designed with robust seismic resistance features, such as base isolation and reinforced connections, to withstand significant seismic events.

Extreme seismic demand on bridges, with SS values exceeding 2.0, represents a critical design challenge requiring state-of-the-art engineering solutions and continuous monitoring to ensure safety during severe seismic events.

SS.title: Short-Period Spectral Acceleration

S1.description: The mapped 1.0-second spectral acceleration at the site before site soil effects are applied, representing seismic demand on longer-period structural systems.

sentences: Bridges experiencing minimal seismic demand with spectral acceleration values under 0.2 are typically subject to low seismic forces, requiring standard design considerations for structural integrity.
Bridges with moderate seismic demand, having spectral acceleration between 0.2 and 0.4, may require enhanced design features to ensure resilience against moderate seismic events.

High seismic demand on bridges, indicated by spectral acceleration values between 0.4 and 0.6, necessitates robust engineering solutions to maintain structural safety and serviceability during significant seismic activity.
Very high seismic demand, with spectral acceleration from 0.6 to 0.8, demands advanced seismic design and retrofitting strategies to protect bridges from severe earthquake impacts.

Bridges facing extreme seismic demand, with spectral acceleration exceeding 0.8, are subject to intense seismic forces and require cutting-edge engineering techniques and continuous monitoring to ensure their structural integrity and public safety.

S1.title: Spectral Acceleration 1.0s

SMS.description: The site-adjusted short-period spectral acceleration that accounts for local soil amplification or attenuation of seismic ground motions.

sentences: Bridges with low seismic demand (SMS from 0 to 0.7) are expected to experience minimal seismic forces, allowing for standard design and construction practices with minimal seismic-specific enhancements.

Bridges with moderate seismic demand (SMS from 0.7 to 1.0) require consideration of seismic forces in design, ensuring that structural components can accommodate moderate ground motion without significant damage.
Bridges with high seismic demand (SMS from 1.0 to 1.3) need robust seismic design measures, including reinforced materials and advanced engineering techniques to withstand substantial seismic forces.

Bridges with very high seismic demand (SMS from 1.3 to 1.6) must incorporate comprehensive seismic resilience strategies, such as base isolation or energy dissipation systems, to maintain structural integrity during strong earthquakes.

Bridges facing extreme seismic demand (SMS exceeding 1.6) are subject to severe ground motions, necessitating cutting-edge engineering solutions and continuous monitoring to ensure safety and functionality during and after seismic events.

SMS.title: Site-Adjusted Spectral Acceleration

SDS.description: The design-level short-period spectral acceleration used directly in seismic design, reflecting reduced demand consistent with code-defined performance objectives.

sentences: Bridges with minimal seismic demand (SDS values from 0 to 0.4) are designed for regions with low seismic activity, where structural reinforcements are minimal and focus on basic safety measures.

Bridges experiencing moderate seismic demand (SDS values from 0.4 to 0.6) require enhanced design considerations to ensure stability and performance during moderate seismic events, incorporating additional reinforcement and damping systems.

High seismic demand on bridges (SDS values from 0.6 to 0.8) necessitates robust structural designs with advanced materials and technologies to withstand significant seismic forces, ensuring the safety and functionality of the infrastructure.

Bridges subjected to very high seismic demand (SDS values from 0.8 to 1.0) are engineered with comprehensive seismic resilience strategies, including base isolation and energy dissipation devices, to protect against severe earthquake impacts.

Extreme seismic demand (SDS values exceeding 1.0) indicates that bridges must be designed with cutting-edge seismic technologies and rigorous safety standards to endure the most intense seismic forces, safeguarding both the structure and its users.

SDS.title: Design Spectral Acceleration

SDCS.description: The seismic design category that classifies overall seismic risk at the site and governs required detailing, analysis rigor, and design provisions.
SDCS.title: Seismic Design Category

PGAM.description: The mapped peak ground acceleration associated with maximum considered earthquake conditions prior to any site-specific adjustments.

sentences: Bridges with a PGAM under 0.3 experience low seismic demand, indicating minimal structural reinforcement is typically required to withstand earthquake forces.
Bridges with a PGAM between 0.3 and 0.5 are subject to moderate seismic demand, necessitating standard seismic design considerations to ensure structural resilience.
Bridges with a PGAM between 0.5 and 0.7 face high seismic demand, requiring enhanced engineering measures and retrofitting to maintain structural integrity during seismic events.
Bridges with a PGAM between 0.7 and 1.0 are exposed to very high seismic demand, demanding rigorous seismic design and frequent inspections to prevent catastrophic failure.
Bridges with a PGAM exceeding 1.0 encounter extreme seismic demand, representing outlier conditions where advanced engineering solutions and continuous monitoring are critical for safety.

PGAM.title: Mapped Peak Ground Acceleration

FPGA.description: The factor for peak ground acceleration adjusted for local site conditions, representing the ground motion intensity expected to be experienced at the bridge location.

sentences: Bridges experiencing minimal seismic impact with FPGA values under 1.2 are expected to perform well with negligible structural concerns during minor seismic events.
Bridges with moderate seismic impact, having FPGA values between 1.2 and 1.3, may require routine inspections to ensure structural integrity under moderate seismic conditions.
Bridges facing significant seismic impact with FPGA values between 1.3 and 1.4 should be evaluated for potential retrofitting to enhance resilience against stronger seismic activities.
Bridges under high seismic impact, with FPGA values between 1.4 and 1.5, are likely to need substantial reinforcement to maintain safety and functionality during major earthquakes.

Bridges experiencing extreme seismic impact with FPGA values exceeding 1.5 represent critical infrastructure that must undergo rigorous seismic assessment and potentially extensive retrofitting to withstand severe seismic forces.

FPGA.title: Ground Motion Factor

MACRO_UNIT_NAME.description: The macro unit name provides the standardized label assigned to a mapped geologic unit, representing a regionally recognized grouping of rock with shared stratigraphic context.
MACRO_UNIT_NAME.title: Geologic Unit Name

MACRO_STRAT_NAME.description: The stratigraphic name identifies the formal stratigraphic unit (such as formation, member, or group) to which the mapped rocks belong, reflecting their position within the geologic column.
MACRO_STRAT_NAME.title: Stratigraphic Unit

MACRO_LITHOLOGY.description: The lithology describes the dominant rock material or materials present in the unit, capturing composition and texture that directly influence mechanical and hydraulic behavior.
MACRO_LITHOLOGY.title: Rock Material Type

MACRO_AGE_MIN.description: The minimum geologic age represents the youngest possible time of formation for the unit, expressed in millions of years, constraining when deposition or emplacement ended.

sentences: Recently formed geologic units, with a minimum age under 50 million years, provide a stable foundation for modern bridges, ensuring minimal geological disturbances and optimal structural support.

Geologically young formations, aged between 50 and 150 million years, offer reliable support for bridge infrastructure, though they may require additional geotechnical assessments to account for potential variability in material properties.

Geologically mature units, ranging from 150 to 250 million years, typically provide well-consolidated foundations for bridges, but may necessitate detailed analysis to address any historical tectonic activity that could impact structural integrity.

Ancient geologic formations, aged between 250 and 350 million years, often present stable but complex conditions for bridge construction, requiring thorough geological surveys to ensure long-term stability and performance.

Prehistoric formations exceeding 350 million years represent extreme geological ages, where bridges must be designed with advanced engineering techniques to accommodate potential challenges from deeply weathered or metamorphosed rock structures.

MACRO_AGE_MIN.title: Minimum Geologic Age

MACRO_AGE_MAX.description: The maximum geologic age represents the oldest possible time of formation for the unit, expressed in millions of years, constraining when deposition or emplacement began.

sentences: Recently formed geological units, with ages under 50 million years, provide a stable foundation for bridges, minimizing seismic risks due to their relatively unaltered state.
Geologically young formations, between 50 and 200 million years, offer reliable support for bridge structures, though they may require careful assessment for potential erosion or weathering effects.
Geologically mature units, aged between 200 and 1000 million years, often exhibit increased stability and reduced seismic activity, making them suitable for long-span bridge construction.

Ancient geological formations, ranging from 1000 to 3000 million years, typically provide robust support for bridges, but may involve complex rock formations requiring specialized engineering solutions.

Prehistoric formations exceeding 3000 million years represent some of the oldest geological units, where bridges may encounter unique challenges due to potential metamorphic transformations and deep-seated faults.

MACRO_AGE_MAX.title: Maximum Geologic Age

MACRO_DESCRIPTION.description: The descriptive text summarizes the geologic characteristics of the unit, including depositional environment, material variability, structure, and notable features relevant to engineering and geotechnical interpretation.
MACRO_DESCRIPTION.title: Geologic Characteristics

STATE_CODE_001.description: The U.S. state or territory in which the bridge is physically located, expressed as a standardized FIPS jurisdiction.
STATE_CODE_001.title: State Code

COUNTY_CODE_003.description: The county (or county-equivalent) in which the bridge is physically located, expressed as a standardized location code.
COUNTY_CODE_003.title: County Code

HIGHWAY_DISTRICT_002.description: The highway agency level that has primary jurisdiction over the roadway network context for the bridge location (state, county, township, or city).
HIGHWAY_DISTRICT_002.title: Highway District Jurisdiction

code_map.8: Other (include toll roads not otherwise indicated or identified above)

ROUTE_PREFIX_005B.description: The classification of the route carried by the bridge by numbering/ownership system (e.g., Interstate, U.S. route, state route, local street, etc.).
ROUTE_PREFIX_005B.title: Route Classification

SERVICE_LEVEL_005C.description: The role of the route carried by the bridge within its route system (mainline, alternate, bypass, spur, ramp/connector, frontage road, etc.).
SERVICE_LEVEL_005C.title: Route Service Role

FEATURES_DESC_006A.description: A free-text description of the feature that the bridge crosses or intersects (e.g., river name, railroad line, roadway name, ravine, canal).
FEATURES_DESC_006A.title: Crossing Feature Description

FACILITY_CARRIED_007.description: A free-text description of the facility that runs on the bridge deck (e.g., the roadway or line being carried across the obstacle).
FACILITY_CARRIED_007.title: Carried Facility Description

LOCATION_009.description: A free-text narrative describing the bridgeâ€™s location context, typically using nearby routes, towns, landmarks, or milepoints.
LOCATION_009.title: Bridge Location Description

code_map.0: Inventory route is not on the Base Network
code_map.1: Inventory route is on the Base Network

BASE_HWY_NETWORK_012.description: An indicator of whether the bridgeâ€™s inventory route is part of the federally defined Base Highway Network.
BASE_HWY_NETWORK_012.title: Base Highway Network

code_map.1: Toll bridge – toll paid to use the structure
code_map.2: On toll road – toll paid to the overall facility
code_map.3: On free road – toll-free structure and highway
code_map.4: Interstate toll segment under Secretarial Agreement
code_map.5: Toll bridge under separate Secretarial Agreement

TOLL_020.description: The toll context describing whether a toll is charged specifically to use the bridge, as part of a tolled facility, or not at all.
TOLL_020.title: Toll Status

code_map.11: State Park, Forest, or Reservation Agency
code_map.12: Local Park, Forest, or Reservation Agency

MAINTENANCE_021.description: The agency or organization that is responsible for maintaining the bridge and performing routine upkeep and repairs.
MAINTENANCE_021.title: Maintenance Agency

code_map.12: Urban - Principal Arterial: Other Freeways or Expressways

FUNCTIONAL_CLASS_026.description: The functional classification of the roadway carried by the bridge, describing its role in the road network (arterial, collector, local; rural/urban).
FUNCTIONAL_CLASS_026.title: Functional Classification

DESIGN_LOAD_031.description: The load model or design loading category the bridge was designed to accommodate (e.g., HS/HL-type truck, pedestrian, railroad).
DESIGN_LOAD_031.title: Design Load Category

MEDIAN_CODE_033.description: The presence and type of median on the bridge, describing whether opposing traffic is separated and how (open/closed/barrier).
MEDIAN_CODE_033.title: Median Type

STRUCTURE_FLARED_035.description: Whether the bridge width flares (widens) near the ends relative to the main portion of the structure.
STRUCTURE_FLARED_035.title: Flared Structure Width

code_map.0: Does not meet standards or required but not provided

RAILINGS_036A.description: Whether the bridge railings as built and present provide adequate safety performance relative to current standards.
RAILINGS_036A.title: Railing Safety Compliance

code_map.0: Does not meet standards or required but not provided

TRANSITIONS_036B.description: Whether the approach-to-bridge transition elements (e.g., rail transitions) provide adequate continuity and safety relative to current standards.
TRANSITIONS_036B.title: Transition Safety Assessment

code_map.0: Does not meet standards or required but not provided

APPR_RAIL_036C.description: Whether the approach guardrail upstream/downstream of the bridge is adequate to safely redirect vehicles relative to current standards.
APPR_RAIL_036C.title: Approach Guardrail Adequacy

code_map.0: Does not meet standards or required but not provided

APPR_RAIL_END_036D.description: Whether the end treatments of the approach guardrail are adequate for crashworthiness relative to current standards.
APPR_RAIL_END_036D.title: Approach Guardrail End TreatmentAdequacy

code_map.1: On the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP)
code_map.3: Possibly eligible or on state/local historic register

HISTORY_037.description: The bridgeâ€™s historic significance status in terms of listing or eligibility for historic registers such as the NRHP.
HISTORY_037.title: Historic Significance Status

NAVIGATION_038.description: Whether a navigable waterway is present and therefore navigation control/permit requirements apply at the crossing.
NAVIGATION_038.title: Navigability Status

code_map.B: Open, posting recommended but not legally implemented
code_map.D: Open, would be posted or closed except for temporary shoring, etc.
code_map.E: Open, temporary structure in place while original is closed
code_map.G: New structure not yet open to traffic
code_map.P: Posted for load (may include temporary load restrictions)
code_map.R: Posted for other restrictions (speed, number of vehicles, etc.)

OPEN_CLOSED_POSTED_041.description: The operational status of the bridge describing whether it is open without restriction, posted with restrictions, or closed to traffic.
OPEN_CLOSED_POSTED_041.title: Bridge Operational Status

SERVICE_ON_042A.description: The primary type of service carried on the bridge deck (highway, railroad, pedestrian/bike, combinations, or complex interchange levels).
SERVICE_ON_042A.title: Service Type

SERVICE_UND_042B.description: The primary type of service that passes beneath the bridge (road, railroad, waterway, combinations, or none).
SERVICE_UND_042B.title: Service Type Below Bridge

code_map.9: Aluminum, wrought iron, or cast iron

STRUCTURE_KIND_043A.description: The primary structural material system used for the main spans of the bridge (e.g., concrete, steel, prestressed concrete, timber).
STRUCTURE_KIND_043A.title: Main Span Material

code_map.6: Box beams or girders - single or spread

STRUCTURE_TYPE_043B.description: The main structural form/design configuration used for the bridge (e.g., slab, girder, truss, arch, suspension, culvert, etc.).
STRUCTURE_TYPE_043B.title: Structure Type

code_map.9: Aluminum, wrought iron, or cast iron

APPR_KIND_044A.description: The primary structural material system used for the approach spans, if approach spans exist (e.g., concrete, steel, timber).
APPR_KIND_044A.title: Approach Span Material

code_map.6: Box beams or girders - single or spread

APPR_TYPE_044B.description: The structural form/design configuration used for the approach spans, if approach spans exist (e.g., girder, slab, truss, culvert, etc.).
APPR_TYPE_044B.title: Approach Span Type

code_map.N: Feature not a highway or railroad

VERT_CLR_UND_REF_054A.description: The feature type used as the reference for reported vertical clearance beneath the bridge (highway, railroad, or other).
VERT_CLR_UND_REF_054A.title: Vertical Clearance Reference

code_map.N: Feature not a highway or railroad

LAT_UND_REF_055A.description: The feature type used as the reference for reported lateral clearance beneath the bridge (highway, railroad, or other).
LAT_UND_REF_055A.title: Lateral Clearance Reference

code_map.8: Very good condition – no problems noted
code_map.5: Fair condition – minor section loss, cracking, or scour
code_map.4: Poor condition – advanced section loss or deterioration
code_map.3: Serious condition – loss of section or fatigue/shear cracks
code_map.2: Critical condition – advanced deterioration or scour
code_map.1: Imminent failure – closed, but repair may restore light service
code_map.0: Failed condition – out of service; beyond corrective action

DECK_COND_058.description: The condition state of the deck element as assessed during inspection, reflecting deterioration such as cracking, spalling, corrosion, or section loss.
DECK_COND_058.title: Deck Condition

code_map.8: Very good condition – no problems noted
code_map.5: Fair condition – minor section loss, cracking, or scour

code_map.3: Serious condition – loss of section or fatigue/shear cracks
code_map.2: Critical condition – advanced deterioration or scour
code_map.1: Imminent failure – closed, but repair may restore light service
code_map.0: Failed condition – out of service; beyond corrective action

SUPERSTRUCTURE_COND_059.description: The condition state of the superstructure as assessed during inspection, reflecting deterioration or damage in main load-carrying members.
SUPERSTRUCTURE_COND_059.title: Superstructure Condition

code_map.8: Very good condition – no problems noted
code_map.5: Fair condition – minor section loss, cracking, or scour

code_map.3: Serious condition – loss of section or fatigue/shear cracks
code_map.2: Critical condition – advanced deterioration or scour
